data.text:
Taking a look back at one of comedy’s most controversial geniuses on the anniversary of his death.

Legendary and controversial comic Sam Kinison passed away thirty-one years ago today, as I write this article, in an auto accident outside of Needles, CA, aged 38.

Ironically, Sam was killed by the embodiment of the people who loved him most when he was alive: a drunk 17 year old kid driving on the wrong side of the road. Kinison himself was a legendary “partier,” had done several runs through rehab, and even had a whole routine about drunk driving in the very same hour-long HBO special, “Breaking the Rules,” that catapulted him to stardom. (“We don’t want to, there’s just no other way to get our car back to the house!”)

Sam and a handful of other comedians — George Carlin, Bill Hicks, Richard Pryor, Brett Butler, Stephen Wright, Heywood Banks, and others — were a huge influence on my philosophy growing up as a teenage hair-metal drummer in the 80’s, and remain so to this day. In particular Sam’s out-of-left-field interpretation of Christianity and the Bible (“I don’t think you’re getting it, ya f***in’ jerks, I didn’t come to be ‘Jesus The Miracle Caterer!”) was a huge bit of thought provocation when I was going through the teen angst of discovering my own religious beliefs, having been raised partly in a tradition…
